para.paratext: Under O.C.G.A. § 24-13-27, a party wishing to require another party to bring tangible items, such as books, writings, or documents in his possession, custody, or control, to the trial may serve a notice to produce on the other party or their counsel. Service is perfected by personal service by sheriff, a deputy sheriff, or any other person not less than 18 years of age, or by registered or certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, where the return receipt is proof of mailing. A party's attorney may be served instead.[1] A failure to produce no longer results in nonsuit or a judgment by default, but is subject to attachment for contempt.

A notice to produce is a part of the Evidence Code, and does not fall under the discovery statute; therefore, the fact that discovery has expired is irrelevant when a party has served a valid notice to produce.[2]

In Aycock v. Household Finance Corp.,[3] the defendant filed a document captioned “Subpoena duces tecum” to require the plaintiff to produce certain documents. The Georgia Court of Appeals pointed out that the term applied only to nonparties and was no longer properly used in Georgia. Since there is “no magic in the nomenclature given a pleading,” it was construed as a notice to produce and should have been allowed. A notice to produce may be used in a criminal case to compel production of books, writings, or other documents in the possession of the state for use at trial or at a pretrial evidentiary hearing where those items are admissible and are needed for use as evidence on behalf of the defendant.[4]
Lyman v. Cellchem Intern., LLC, 335 Ga. App. 266, 779 S.E.2d 474 (2015), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 300 Ga. 475, 796 S.E.2d 255 (2017).
Aycock v. Household Finance Corp. of Georgia, 142 Ga. App. 207, 235 S.E.2d 578 (1977).
